overview: VAT refunds on building new homes and conversions - how to claim, application form and guidance notes
title: Building a new home and VAT

table.body:
You can apply for a VAT refund on building materials and services if you’re: 

+ building a new home 
+ converting a property into a home 
+ building a non-profit communal residence - eg a hospice
+ building a property for a charity 

The building work and materials have to [qualify](/vat-building-new-home/eligibility "Eligibility") and you must [apply](/vat-building-new-home/how-to-claim "How to claim") to HM Revenue & Customs within 3 months of completing the work. 

*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The [application form](/vat-building-new-home/how-to-claim "How to claim") has guidance on what building projects and materials qualify for a VAT refund. The basics are listed below.

##New homes

The home must:

- be separate and self-contained
- be for you or your family to live or holiday in 
- not be for business purposes (you can use one room as a work from home office)

##Conversions

The building being converted must usually be a non-residential building. Residential buildings qualify if they haven't been lived in for at least 10 years. 

##Communal and charity buildings 

You may get a VAT refund if the building is for a charity or is a non-profit communal residential building - eg a  children's home or hospice. 

##What doesn’t qualify

You can’t get a VAT refund for:

- projects in the Channel Islands
- materials or services that don’t have any VAT - eg they were zero-rated or exempt
- professional or supervisory fees - eg architects
- hiring machinery or equipment
- buildings for business purposes - unless it's for a charity
- buildings that can’t be sold or used separately from another property because of a planning permission condition
- building materials that aren't permanently attached to or part of the building itself
- fitted furniture, some electrical and gas appliances, carpets or garden ornaments

*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
To claim the VAT refund, send HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) form VAT 431NB or 431C. The forms include guidance notes (eg how to work out your VAT) and the postal address.

$D [Download form VAT 431NB, VAT refunds for new houses (PDF, 410KB)](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/downloadFile?contentID=HMCE_PROD1_029776 "Download form VAT 431NB, VAT refunds for new houses (PDF, 410KB)"){:rel="external"}  
[Download form VAT 431C, VAT refunds for conversions' (PDF, 454KB)](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/downloadFile?contentID=HMCE_PROD1_029775 "Download form "VAT431C, VAT refunds for conversions (PDF, 454KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##What you need to know 

You must claim within 3 months of the building work being completed. 

You'll usually get the refund in 30 working days of sending the claim. 

You must include the following with your claim: 

+ bank details - so the refund can be paid
+ the planning permission 
+ proof the building work is finished - eg a letter from your local authority
+ a full set of building plans
+ the invoices - including tenders or estimations if the invoice isn't itemised
+ bills and any credit notes
+ proof the VAT has been paid - eg bank statements

VAT invoices must be valid and show the correct rate of VAT or they won't be accepted. For invoices not in Sterling, convert the amounts into Sterling.

$C 
**VAT Helpline**  
0845 010 9000  
Monday to Friday 8am to 6pm    
$C

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[VAT]: Value Added Tax
